title: Everything goes to pot for Adelaide man as kitchen fire reveals cannabis crop - Yahoo7
text:
Share Everything goes to pot for Adelaide man as kitchen fire reveals cannabis crop - Yahoo7 It was double trouble for an Adelaide man after his kitchen caught fire while he was cooking lunch for his dog. Close Double trouble in Adelaide’s south as a house fire reveals cannabis plants UP NEXT VIDEO Cannabis found after Troy Bowers burned cooking lunch for dog in McLaren Vale fire. Source: Seven News Double trouble in Adelaide’s south as a house fire reveals cannabis plants 
Troy Bowers suffered burns to his hand, but his pain got worse when police allegedly located six cannabis plants in the home. 
Mr Bowers had been frying a schnitzel for his dog Hugo when the fire broke out. 
“We put the oil on and a couple of minutes later heard some crackling and went in and it was all on fire; smoke everywhere,” he said. Police say they found six cannabis plants in the building after the fire was put out. Photo: 7 News 
He raised the alarm and got his partner and their 18-month-old daughter to safety, burning his hand in the process. 
Hugo and another pet dog, Poppy, were also rescued. 
“I think on the scale of things were very lucky,” Mr Bowers said. Beachgoers watch men with 'psychotic' weapons bash man 
“Not too much damage at the end of the day and, yeah, very lucky.” 
Firefighters quickly extinguished the blaze but when the smoke cleared, police allegedly discovered the hydroponic set up in the home. Troy Bowers walks away from his McLaren Vale home with police. Photo: 7 News 
Mr Bowers will now front court after being reported for cultivating cannabis. 
Luckily, damage from the fire was restricted to the kitchen. 
The Country Fire Service says the blaze is a timely reminder not to leave food cooking unattended on stove tops. 
“Please ensure somebody’s around to make sure it’s looked after and this sort of thing doesn’t happen,” Richard Brookes from the CFS said.
